conclusion: In a three-dimensional Cartesian coordinate system, the positive direction of the x-axis is horizontally to the right, and the positive direction of the y-axis is vertically upward.
A uniform magnetic field is introduced into the system.

A current-carrying conductor rod cd with mass m=10g and length L=50cm is horizontally suspended by two insulating strings of equal length in the positive direction of the x-axis and remains stationary.
The direction of the magnetic induction intensity is the same as the negative direction of the z-axis and its magnitude is B1=1.0T.
The tension in the thin wire is exactly zero.
Determine the magnitude and direction of the current I1 in cd.
The magnetic force on a current-carrying conductor in a magnetic field is given by Fm = I L B sin(theta).
I is the current, L is the length of the conductor in the magnetic field, B is the magnetic field strength, theta is the angle between the current and the magnetic field.

premise: The rod is horizontal and the magnetic field is in the negative z-direction, theta = 90 degrees.

conclusion: The rod remains stationary, so the net force on it must be zero.

premise: The net force on the rod must be zero.
conclusion: The magnetic force upward must balance the gravitational force downward: Fm = Fg
To determine the direction of the current, we use the right-hand rule.
